nodes.text: Partial modelling using Boolean networks (BNs) can be deployed as an inductive discovery procedure to develop economic theory and provide predictive models of the economy
BNs have been applied in fields like systems biology and are reported to frequently yield results described as having high predictive power
A sufficiently complicated model can be calibrated to reproduce known data without necessarily having true predictive power for novel or nontrivial events
Combining partial BN models requires simplification such as excluding node values that produce multiple steady states and omitting feedback loops to avoid oscillations

An alternative 'dashboard' approach is preferable: keep multiple model types mostly separate so each captures complementary aspects of reality rather than patching models together into a single large model
The term 'predict' in systems biology is often used loosely to mean reproducing known results or calibration rather than blind-tested forecasting of novel events
Flexibility of BNs and other complex models can lead to 'sloppy parameters' where many parameters cannot be determined from available data, reducing model reliability
Pruning destabilizing features like feedback loops to enable model combination removes key system structure and can make the combined model less realistic
BNs can include components with minimal quantitative data (e.g., cultural or religious variables) without significant loss of apparent predictive power in some contexts
BNs can be converted into continuous dynamical systems configured as ordinary differential equations, enabling alternative analysis

Empirical examples from biology and medicine show that different model classes or small models can outperform large or improperly structured models for prediction (examples: stochastic effects in yeast, combined ODE/agent-based cancer models, simple cardiac toxicity model outperformed large biophysical models)
The core limitation is model structure and parameter identifiability rather than model size; adding nodes or combining models does not necessarily address structural mismatches or hidden dynamics

Including poorly quantified variables or converting BNs to ODEs does not guarantee capturing essential dynamics like stochastic population effects or interference phenomena requiring alternative probabilistic frameworks
Model size should be limited and multiple complementary models used as a dashboard, because simple models often give better predictive results though they are incomplete representations

Before combining models, investigate incentives and funding sources that shape assumptions and research questions, since incentives can bias model construction and application domains like finance have strong external influences

Limitations of the BN partial-modelling strategy include pruning of difficult features (feedback, money, behavior) and proliferation of undeterminable parameters, making it unlikely to solve predictive and structural problems in economics
